Graphical abstract We comprehensively discuss the recycling and reuse of graphite anode from the spent LIBs to figure out the issues related to the current spent LIBs recycling technologies. This recycling of graphite will provide an in-depth understanding of the graphite history, importance, properties, and future guidelines that can lead to attaining economical spent LIBs recycling technologies by efficient graphite recycling. Demand for graphite in the forthcoming years to develop Li-ion batteries (LIBs) with the goal of driving electric vehicles (EV) and its requirement in multifarious energy storage applications as an electrode. The emerging sector of LIB-based EVs, along with portable electronics, produces an inevitable volume of batteries in the e-waste stream. The main reason for the lower percentage of recycling (at present, <5%) is due to the recovery of economically rich metals like Li, Ni, and Co. However, complete recycling technologies, including the strategic material graphite, which is available in a massive amount of spent LIBs, are urgently needed to be updated to ensure the reuse of all components. This approach lifts the recycling process to develop an economic one besides the geostrategic and environmental policy aspects. Here, we summarize the importance of graphite and its demand and specify the reasons to recycle the graphite from spent LIBs along with its development as an anode in detail. Additionally, the approach of the current recycling process of graphite in lab-scale and industries for various applications, including energy storage, are discussed with the highlights of future progress. Keywords Recycling Lithium-ion batteries Graphite Anode Capacitor 1 Introduction The 2019 Nobel prize in chemistry was presented to Prof. John Goodenough, Prof. Stanley Whittingham, and Dr. Akira Yoshino for the development of lightweight, rechargeable, and high-energy Lithium-ion batteries (LIB), which has underpinned the revolution of portable electronics and electric vehicles (EV) [1–3]. Since 1990, portable electronic devices based on LIBs such as mobile phones, laptops, tablets, and wearable electronic devices have been popping up and have become the most gifted candidates due to the huge demand for well-timed and efficient processing and sharing of global information [4]. Likewise, the global electric vehicle market has drawn significant interest in the past decade to meet targets for dropping greenhouse gas emissions and improving air quality [5], thus finding a solution to the rising carbon footprint and other environmental impacts. For the last seven years, the momentum for electric mobility has increased exponentially worldwide, and in 2017 the total sales of EVs surpassed one million cars per year for the first time [5]. The EV market is estimated to grow from 3,269,671 units in 2019 to 26,951,318 units in 2030 [6] and will make 40% of all passenger vehicles by 2040, according to an International Energy Agency report [7]. Besides, LIB is projected to lead in the EV market share in the impending years [8]. The demand for LIB in power electronics and automotive applications is anticipated to rise significantly in the next 15–20 years [9] due to their high energy, power density, and long lifespan, along with cost reductions by a factor of five over the last decade [10]. Energy Information Administration estimated that by 2025, cumulative sales of EVs would reach ∼55 million [11]. This success story of LIB is keeping the world on its track of development, however generating a pile of spent LIBs that could end up in the trash. Presently, the bulk of spent LIB from consumer electronics is mainly landfilled or disposed of without considering the environmental regulations regarding end-of-life batteries. Furthermore, the volume of spent LIB is likely to grow explosively as LIBs from EVs start to reach their end-of-life. Hence, it's high time for the researchers to be serious about LIB recycling, preserving natural resources, and addressing battery end-of-life issues [12,13]. Spent LIBs are recyclable and may also represent a valuable source of different materials and minerals; this can be considered a secondary source of critical materials to guarantee a steady supply chain [5]. Even so, due to technical and economic factors, less than 5% are recycled today [12]. The vast quantity of used LIBs will hit 2 million metric tons per year predicted by industrial analysts; however, storing waste batteries is environmentally undesirable and risky for human health. This makes the researchers think about the cost-effective, environment-friendly, and energy-efficient “concept of 3R” (recycle, recover, & reuse) to avoid the rapidly increasing stream of LIB waste [5,12]. A battery cell, the basic unit of LIB, is a sealed container with two electrodes (anode and cathode), a separator, and an electrolyte. The electrodes comprise metallic conductor foils (Al and Cu) with active material coating on the surface. The cathode is generally over Al-foil with a range of active material compositions such as LiCoO2, LiMn2O4, LiFePO4, LiNi1/3Mn1/3Co1/3O2, and LiNi0.8Co0.15 Al0.05O2. The anode is mostly Cu-foil with carbonaceous material (graphite) loading [14,15]. The electrodes are fabricated by mixing active material (∼80%) with up to 10% of conductive additives (carbon black) and a polymer binder (polyvinylidene fluoride, PVDF). The electrolytes are prepared by dissolving lithium salts (LiPF6, LiClO4, LiAsF6, LiBF4, etc.) in a mixture of linear and cyclic carbonate solution either by volumetric or gravimetric scale. The separator, mostly polypropylene, is an electrically insulating membrane that avoids the contact between two electrodes and hence the electrical short-circuit but is permeable to ions [16]. All these components of LIB have value and can be recovered and reused. The estimated weight percentage of these materials in the battery is nearly 31% cathode active material (Li metal oxide or Li mixed metal oxides), 22% anode active material (Graphite), 17% copper, 15% electrolyte solution, 8% Aluminium, 4% carbon black and binder along with 3% separator plastics [12] as displayed in Fig. 1 . The battery cells, which are mainly cylindrical or prismatic, can be connected to form modules [17–19]. As the LIB boom continues, both battery researchers and environmentalists are giving different reasons to recycle and also working on enhancements in recycling technology. Spent LIB recycling can be a remedy for two major challenges of LIB technology, such as overall production cost and long-term material supply for future demand [20]. Thus, recycling represents a practical route for the restoration of LIB components, reducing the consumption of resources related to the production of main raw materials. The cost of recovered materials from spent LIB account for more than half of a battery's cost. Many studies have been focused on recovering metallic compounds (Li, Ni, Co, Mn, Cu & Al) from the spent cathode through hydrometallurgy or pyrometallurgy or the combination of both processes. But there are only limited studies that have been dedicated to recycling and reuse of Graphite, state-of-the-art anode material, the second largest component, ∼22% (w/w) of LIB [21–27]. In the last few years, the global graphite industry has steadily growing demand and tight supply due to an unexpected boom in EVs. According to a recent report by Allied Market Research, the graphite market was valued at USD 14.3 billion in 2019 and is projected to reach USD 21.6 billion by 2027, with an increasing Compound annual growth rate,CAGR of 5.3% in the forecast period of 2020–2027 [28]. The battery industry mostly prefers natural graphite (NG) for the production of anodes for drive LIB batteries due to its ease of availability and low price compared to synthetic graphite (SG). Graphite has been categorized as a critical/strategic mineral by the governments of the United States and Europe as it is used in many energy-related applications [29]. The need for graphite for a fast-growing energy future filled with EVs and energy storage systems will upsurge in the coming years. The graphite used in LIB batteries, ∼25 kg graphite for a single LIB in all- EV, is either landfilled or sent to an incineration furnace after two-three years of life [30]. Recycle, recover and reuse (3R concept) graphite may offer several economic, environmental, and health welfares; moreover, recovered graphite (RG) material can be either converted into graphene or re-used as such for different potential applications (Fig. 2 ). This review presents the current status and future demand of different graphite recycling strategies along with the challenges and opportunities of using RG from spent LIB for various applications. We also explain the crystal structure, physiochemical properties along with the mechanism of alkali metal intercalation in the graphite crystal lattice. We anticipate this review may help to advance the recovery and reusability of RG anode along with cathode shortly and hence resolve peacefully the problems of graphite crisis and environmental issues linked with spent LIB disposal. 2 Importance of graphite – a mineral with extreme properties and numerous uses Graphite, a mineral with metallic and non-metallic properties that has been used by humankind for millennia, and as technology advances, its demand is growing. It is a grey crystalline carbon allotrope, which is naturally found in metamorphic and igneous rocks. It is exceptionally soft with a Mohs hardness of 1–2, a theoretical density of 2.26 g cm−3, and a specific gravity of 2.2. However, it is an excellent conductor of heat and electricity with high stiffness and strength, chemical inertness, corrosion resistance, highly lubricating, and can sustain its firmness up to a temperature of ∼3600 °C [31]. Because of these unique properties, graphite has been used by mankind from the historic period. As it resembles the metal lead, it was also known as plumbago or black lead. As early as the Neolithic age, graphite was used in decorating pottery, and in AD 1500, a very large deposit of graphite was found in the Borrowdale area of England, which was used for forming smooth refractory cannonball moulds during the supremacy of Queen Elizabeth I (1558-1603) [32]. Since then, it has been used for refractories, brake linings, batteries, steelmaking, and also as a lubricant. The first documented use of graphite in pencils was reported in 1565. The name “graphite” was coined by the German chemist and mineralogist Abraham Gottlob Werner in 1789 and is derived from the Greek word “graphein,” which means “to write”; it represents the main use of graphite to make lead for pencils. The term “pencil lead” was used until 1779, when the German-Swedish chemist Carl Wilhelm Scheele proved that graphite is a form of carbon, not lead [33]. In 1795, French artist Conte brought the idea of mixing graphite and clay to produce pencils, and after several years in 1830, the pencil-making industry started in Keswick, which used a bulk quantity of graphite powder to mix with clay to produce pencils of varying hardness [34]. The use of graphite or carbon electrodes for the first time was linked with the invention of ‘electric arc light’ by Humphrey Devy in the first decade of 1800 [35]. From the starting of the 20th century onwards, carbon-based electrodes were widely used for different electrolytic and electrothermic processes [36,37]. In the 1980s, Rachid Yazami, a Moroccan scientist and engineer, introduced the concept of reversible Li-ion intercalation into graphite electrode in an electrochemical cell containing polymer electrolyte that led to the discovery of commercial LIB with graphite as an anode [38]. In 2004, Andre Geim and Konstantin Novoselv [39,40] at the University of Manchester, UK, isolated and characterized single atom thick graphene, the 2D wonder material from graphite. In addition to the rising demand for graphite to drive LIBs, the commercialization of graphene for various applications connected with the latest technologies and innovations is expected to flourish the graphite market in a time-bound manner. Graphite is the most commonly used anode material in commercial LIBs owing to its outstanding stability, sustained over several thousand cycles. Graphite can be naturally mined, natural graphite (NG), or artificially produced, synthetic graphite (SG) (Fig. 3 ). The NG can be further graded into flake (crystalline), vein (lump), and microcrystalline (amorphous) based on the degree of crystallinity and physical characteristics. Flake graphite consists of highly crystallized flat-plate-like particles with a purity of 75–90%. They are generally formed as a result of the regional metamorphism of carbonaceous materials in sedimentary rocks. As a result of the perfect crystal structure with 90–95% carbon content, their density, thermal, and electrical conductivity values which are close to the theoretical maximum [37,41]. Lump/ vein graphite is hydrothermal in origin and occurs in veins of metamorphic or igneous rocks. It has various forms, and particle size varies from extremely fine to coarse. It has the highest degree of cohesiveness and high electrical conductivity. Microcrystalline/amorphous graphite normally consists of very fine grains with a low degree of crystallinity and is formed as a result of coal metamorphism. This graphite form has a high degree of graphitization, and graphite content ranges from 25 to 85%. SG can be made by high-temperature processing of amorphous carbon derived from precursors such as organic materials, petroleum, or coal [42]. During the 1800’s Edward Goodrich Acheson accidentally discovered SG while trying to manufacture carborundum (silicon carbide) in an electric furnace containing silica and amorphous carbon. He could observe the presence of graphite crystals, an unexpected reaction product within the furnace. By removing silica from this reaction system, highly crystalline graphite could now be produced from various amorphous carbon precursors [31,43,44]. These are generally more expensive than NG and have high carbon content. Based on the production method, they come in mainly two forms, like electro graphite/electrodes and graphite blocks, made using petroleum coke as a precursor. Electrodes are mainly used in electric arc furnaces used for melting steel and iron, and graphite blocks are mainly used for energy storage in the solar industry. However, NG has substantial merit in production cost and energy consumption comparison with SG [31,45]. Furthermore, all grades of naturally mined and synthesized graphite cannot be used directly in battery applications, as it requires a high degree of crystallinity, and purity in addition to large flake sizes [29]. Hence, flake and vein graphite with a high degree of graphitization are the two options that can be used as anode active material in LIBs. But, the vein graphite is fairly expensive due to limited availability. Hence, flake graphite is the main choice for the application of battery anode; it is also suitable for many other applications [46]. Based on the size of flakes, natural flake graphite (NFG) is divided into three groups such as large, medium, and fine flakes. Large flakes have a carbon content of 94–97% with particle size greater than ∼177 µm, the medium (144–177 µm) and fine (<144 µm) flakes are generally preferred for battery electrode production [47]. However, before using it as the active material for electrode preparation, NFG should undergo some pretreatment steps as it is not pure enough to consider battery-grade graphite. Moreover, NFG is anisotropic in nature, which unfavorably affects the adherence of particles to the current collector. Also, it shows poor rate capability due to difficulties in Li-intercalation into highly oriented basal and edge-plane surfaces. To improve the usage of NFG, it can be subjected to thermal/ chemical treatment. It can also be converted into spherical graphite by rolling graphite flakes using mechanical methods, and the resulting potato-shaped spherical graphite generally exhibits > 99.9% carbon purity [48]. Spherical particle graphite (SPG) is more expensive (∼3 times) than flake graphite as the yield of production is only 30%. Currently, SG is acting as a crucial component for efficient LIB technology. It is also possible to produce SPG from SG, which is clearly a costlier option than NFG. The SPG is the option to meet the increasing demand for graphite, mainly in such countries where the NG source is limited. The main advantage of SG over NG is its high purity (97–99.9%) as a result of high-temperature synthesis [49]. The electrochemical performance of LIB anode based on SG depends on factors like crystal size, heat treatment temperature, and processing atmosphere inside the furnace. The electrochemical performance of SG was compared with NG, and reports show NG exhibits less irreversible capacity than SG. This is due to the fact that NG has smooth edge planes, whereas SG has a lot of crevices in the edge plane, which results in increased surface area and high irreversible capacity. The NG forms on the earth's crust at a temperature of ∼750 °C, which is easily achievable, but it requires high pressure of ∼75,000 psi for a period of ∼10 million years. Whereas at ambient pressure, synthesizing graphite from amorphous carbon, it requires a very high temperature of ∼3000 °C for a reasonable time period [31]. Graphite consists of planar layers of sp2 hybridized carbon atoms arranged in a hexagonal pattern. The distance between the in-plane carbon atom is ∼0.1421 nm, with a 120° bond angle and ∼430 kJ mol−1 in-plane bonding energy. The layers are arranged in ‘AB sequence’, in which only half of the carbon atoms have carbon atoms above or below them in the neighboring layer. The carbon layers (graphene layers) are ∼0.354 nm apart and are pinned by weak van der Waals interaction formed by delocalized π-orbital. This hexagonal Graphite (ABAB stacking, Bernal Stacking) is the thermodynamically stable form of graphite (space group D6h4-PG3/mmc) with unit cell dimensions a = 2.46 Å, and c = 6.71 Å. This was first proposed by Bernal [50,51] and further modified by Charlier, Gonze, and Michenaud [52]; Chung [53], and Telling, Barbary, and Heggie [54,55]. Graphite is also known to exhibit rhombohedral arrangement (ABCABCstacking) such that the first and third carbon layers counterbalance each other (Fig. 4 ). This is thermally unstable and is described by the space group D3d5–R3m, with unit cell dimensions a = 2.56 Å c = 10.06 Å. Rhombohedral Graphite is generally represented as an extended stacking fault in hexagonal graphite, and it cannot be isolated in pure form. SG predominantly contains hexagonal graphite, whereas NG mostly contains a combination of both (<40% rhombohedral graphite). Rhombohedral Graphite is mainly produced by extensive grinding or shear deformation of hexagonal graphite and transforms back to a more stable hexagonal form by heating above 1600 °C [56]. Hence, the NG is generally subjected to high-temperature treatment before its applications to reduce the proportion of rhombohedral graphite in it. The graphene layers in graphite can slide over each other as they are held together by weak interplanar interactions, and hence, they are useful as a lubricant or in pencils. In addition to the use of battery anode material, it has various applications as a moderator in nuclear reactors and as a refractory material in the furnace. Graphite is an engineering material with a richness of physics and chemistry in it and exists in two forms, hexagonal (alpha) and rhombohedral (beta), with similar physical properties. It has a giant covalent structure, made up of layers of carbon atoms (1s 22s22p2), with four valence electrons for bonding. Each carbon atom uses three of its electrons (2s, 2px & 2py) to form strong covalent σ bonds between three carbon atoms in the same plane directed 120° apart. The fourth electron (2pz) in each carbon atom become delocalized and results in loosely bound π-electrons of high mobility, which can carry charges and hence play a crucial role in the electronic properties of graphite. The graphene layers are stacked in the “c”-crystallographic axis by weak van der Waals forces, and hence it has soft, slippery nature and is used in pencils and as dry lubricants. Moreover, the anisotropic nature of graphite can be illustrated by all of its physical and chemical properties; for example, thermal and electrical conductivity is very high in the direction parallel with carbon layer planes (“a” direction), whereas low electrical and thermal conductivity can be observed in “c”-direction. Due to strong in-plane covalent bonding, it exhibits a high melting point and is insoluble in both water and organic solvents. The low density of graphite is because of the large interplanar space between graphene sheets. Graphite is the only non-metal that still conducts electricity and has an electronic band structure of semimetal (Fermi energy of 20 meV) with a band overlap energy of about 0.03–0.04 eV [57,58]. The hexagonal lattice of graphite is also revealed by the shape of its Brillouin zone, a hexagonal prism with edges HKH and H′ K′ H′ [53]. Magnetic properties of graphite are mainly ruled by circular currents that move above and below the planar carbon layers, and it shows exceptional diamagnetism due to the presence of delocalized electrons. It has the second largest diamagnetic susceptibility after superconductors. In addition, it shows strong anisotropy, susceptibility at room temperature is about −21 × 10−6 emu g−1 along the direction perpendicular to graphene layers (χc) and −0.4 × 10−6 emu g−1 along the axis parallel to carbon layers (χa) [53,59]. Grinding of graphite particles to a size < 20 nm causes π-electron deficiency, which in turn leads to loss of diamagnetism. Anisotropic electrical and magnetic properties of single-crystal graphite are temperature dependent. The strength of graphite upsurges with temperature due to the relief of internal stresses, and plastic deformation occurs at a temperature greater than 2500 °C. The specific resistance value of NG is 10−4 Ωm along the a-axis and 1 Ωm along the c-axis at room temperature [60]. On account of anisotropy, graphite is capable of undergoing intercalation type chemical reactions by letting the reactant/intercalant be present in the space between carbon layers, forming graphite intercalation compounds (GICs), as a result of charge transfer between graphite and intercalant [53]. Surface compounds and substitutional compounds are the other two types of graphite compounds in addition to GICs. Surface compounds are the result of a reaction with graphite surface atoms present on the planar surface perpendicular to the c-axis or due to edge atoms with free valence bonds. The substitutional compounds of graphite hold foreign species substitutionally. Whereas GICs are interstitial compounds in which the foreign species is contained within the interplanar spaces between the graphene layers. When the intercalant is occupying the space between carbon layers, there is a chance of expansion of interplanar space without disrupting the graphite structure due to weak π-bonds, which hold the carbon atoms of adjutant layers together. Moreover, the intercalation phenomenon in graphite is both physical and chemical in nature, and the type of bonding between intercalant and carbon depends on the intercalant species. Based on the nature of bonding, there are two types of GICs, covalent and ionic. Covalent GICs are formed due to the presence of conjugated double bonds within the carbon planes, and there is a transformation of carbon bonding from sp2 (trigonal) to sp3 (tetrahedral) hybridization form. The semi-metallic property of graphite is missing in this group of compounds and is non-conducting in nature. GICs in this category are limited, including graphite oxide (GO), carbon monofluoride/polycarbonate monofluoride, and tetra carbon monofluoride (C4F). Ionic GICs, in which bonding is partially ionic and includes graphite salts, graphite-alkali-metal compounds, graphite-halogen compounds, and graphite-metal chloride compounds. Some of them exhibit a low degree of ionicity, and they are not ionic but are grouped as ionic intercalation compounds. The nature of ionic bonding is complicated as many intercalate to retain their molecular identity within the graphite lattice. In the presence of surplus external intercalates, ionic GICs exhibit a well-ordered layered structure and are known as lamellar compounds. These have received more attention than covalent GICs, due to superior electrical conductivities. As explained by, Rüdorff and Daumas–Herold's models, they can be classified based on the number of concentration stages, which represents the number of carbon layers between two intercalate layers (Fig. 5 ). The GICs exhibit outstanding physical and chemical properties in comparison with pristine graphite, and these properties are a function of intercalant species and the quality of graphite. GICs have been used as electrode material in batteries due to their characteristics, such as high electrical conductivity and easy diffusion of electroactive species between the carbon layers. Moreover, there have been reports showing a wide application of GICs in graphene synthesis, electrical/thermal conductors, catalysis, and energy storage applications [61–63]. 3 Graphite –the state of art anode material in LIB After the successful demonstration of reversible Li-intercalation by Prof. Rachid Yazami, Sony Corporation commercialized the first prototype of LIB in 1991 with Lithium intercalated graphite as anode [61,64], and up till now, it is a part of most of the LIBs used in mobile phones, laptop computers and also in EVs. Despite extensive anode active material research over the last ∼25–30 years, graphite remains the prominent anode active material as it is safe, reliable, and is capable of providing adequate energy density. Moreover, it exhibits a quite reversible intercalation/ deintercalation of Li-ions with a stable structure and delivers a gravimetric and volumetric capacity of 372 mAh g−1 and 840 mAh cm−3, respectively, with low lithiation potential (∼0.1 V vs. Li) and steady discharge curve [65–67]. 3.1 Major stages in the development of graphite negative electrode for LIB As early as 1938, Rüdorff and Hoffman were the first to propose the use of graphite in rechargeable cells [68], with a model that could not explain the mechanism of intercalation reaction. Then, Herold studied the reaction between lithium vapor and graphite to understand the concept of lithiation [69,70], but it was confirmed only after the synthesis of various Li-GICs, LiC6, LiC12, and LiC8 by Juza and Wehle [71–73]. Intercalation of Li-into graphite indicates the insertion of Li ions between the graphene layers, and this transformation to GIC is a staged process with the onset of stage 4 GIC, and continuous lithiation leads to stage 1 GIC. As stated earlier, there are two models of ion intercalation which explain the staging process; the Rüdorff model explains the sequential filling up mechanism, that is, the intercalation of Li-ions into alternating interplanar spaces without structural distortions. Whereas the Daumas-Herold model or ‘classical pleated –layer model’ states that intercalation would bring deformation around the inserted Li ions in the bendable carbon layers [74–76]. Guerard and Herold reported the synthesis of LiC6 as a product of the solid-state reaction between Li and Graphite [72]. Besenhard and Eichinger [77–79] first reported the reversible electrochemical insertion of Li-ions into graphite up to LiC6. Besides, the same group proposed the use of LiC6 as an anode in LIB. By the use of polymer electrolytes in 1977, Armand and Touzan explained the use of graphite as a promising intercalation host [80]. Various research groups recommended replacing Li metal anode to overcome safety issues, lithium plating, and stripping efficiency [81–84]. The concept of ‘rocking-chair’/LIB with two intercalation materials for both anode and cathode, with the shuttle of ions from one electrode to another, was proposed in the late 1970s by Armand and was established by Lazzari and Scrosati in 1980 [85–87]. However, the “rocking-chair” battery gained significant attention in 1991, when Sony Corporation and the Asahi team led by Nishi [64,88] successfully commercialized LIB with LiCoO2 developed by Goodenough and co-workers [89] as cathode and graphite, motivated by reported electrochemical lithiation of graphite by Yazami and Touzain [38] as the anode, in which Li-ions shuttle from cathode to anode during charging and discharging and this resulted in a 3.6 V LIB cell with an energy density of 80 Wh kg−1 [41,77]. 3.2 Mechanism of Li-intercalation in graphite The intercalation reactions are reversible, topotactic solid-state reactions and the product of such reactions- ‘intercalation compounds’ are different from inclusion and interstitial compounds [90]. The term ‘intercalation’ was used for the first time by McDonnell et al. [91] to represent the compounds like C8K and C8Br, and Rüdorff used the phrase ‘intercalation compounds’ to represent chemical derivatives of graphite in his review titled “Graphite intercalation compounds” [70]. During the intercalation of guest species into graphite, there is oxidation-reduction between the reagents and expansion of inter-planar space without damaging the lattice array [92]. Moreover, the intercalation mechanism depends on the perfect layered structure of graphite. Bajaj and co-workers [169] developed the preparation process of reduced graphene oxide at room temperature with the RG after Li separation. In this process, outer cases of Al, which were used to cover the LIB pack, were employed as a reducing agent in the presence of HCl. Moreover, the stainless-steel (SS) cover was also compared to evaluate the reducing ability of graphene oxide at room temperature and in heat treatment. However, the higher standard reduction potential of Al removed the majority of oxygen-containing functional groups from GO at room temperature as compared to Fe (which would be present majorly in SS), which facilitated the attainment of 112 F g−1 using 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte. Also, this prepared graphene from waste graphite and Al could be able to drive 20,000 cycles to trigger the industries/researchers to prepare reduced graphene oxide (rGO) on a large scale for energy storage applications in the absence of commercial reducing agents. As mentioned earlier, the graphite source will be available in a larger amount compared to other metals present in the spent LIBs, and its weight varies on the sources ranging from mobile phones to EVs. 5.2.2.2 Li-ion capacitor In this modern electronic revolutionary era, most of the energy storage devices influenced by the LIBs and supercapacitors have their critical drawbacks in providing high power (<1000 W kg−1) and energy density (<10 Wh kg−1), respectively. By bringing the benefits of LIBs and supercapacitors, researchers assembled the lithium-ion hybrid capacitor (LIC) using the EDLC behavior cathode, and intercalation type anode fetches high energy and power densities along with long term cycling stability (Fig. 8 a). However, noteworthy accomplishments have been reached so far for carbon materials by employing both the cathode (i.e., capacitive type) and anode (i.e., intercalation), yet, a great challenge is still remained to design low-cost and high-performance energy storage devices in the LIC configuration [167,170,171]. Generally, the transformation of NG into an intercalation-type anode needs harmful acids, requires an inert atmosphere to heat the graphite at a higher temperature, and makes the process more economical. In view of these issues, Aravindan et al. [26] shredded the spent LIBs magnetically separated the ferrous materials to gain a mixture of the coarse and fine fractions that contain a combination of cathode and anode materials. Further, carbon was collected after lixiviation with sulfuric acid at 80 °C for 4 h to examine their electrochemical property in the half-cell configuration, which displayed ∼97% initial reversible capacity. Impressively, the recycled graphite assembled as the anode with commercial AC provides an energy density of ∼112 Wh kg−1, further encouraged to improve the performance of the RG material. Divya et al. [24] upgraded the energy density of the LIC up to 185.5 Wh kg−1 via placing the RG as an anode with simple heat treatment at 800 °C for 3 h (Fig. 8e). Moreover, they evaluated the temperature performance of the LIC, and the galvanostatic charge-discharge curves of the LIC confirmed the higher charge-discharge time at high temperatures than the ambient conditions ( Fig. 8c). The LIC used commercial AC as the cathode and maintained ∼75% capacity retention at 25 °C after 2000 cycles. The above results further persuade the researchers/industries to build other high energy storage devices such as Na-ion capacitors using the spent graphite material in a cost-effective approach. 5.2.2.3 Na-ion capacitor As mentioned earlier, the increasing price of Li and restriction of lithium sources in the world forces us to replace Li with other earth-abundant elements like Na in the energy-storage devices [172–175]. It is well-known that Na cannot be intercalated into graphite-like Li due to its large size, and the instability of binary-GICs limits the capacity to 30 mAh g−1, whereas the graphite could achieve ∼372 mAh g−1 for Li. Later, Jache and Adelhelm [176] found a way to store Na+ effectively in graphite via a solvent-co-intercalation process using the glyme-based electrolyte (Fig. 8b). Also, the ether-based electrolytes have the potential to be stable below ∼4 V vs. Na, which forms a thin SEI layer on the anode surface and leads to attaining higher initial coulombic efficiency as compared to the ester-based electrolytes. Moreover, the ether-based electrolytes form the stable ternary GICs and attract the researchers to explore how and when Na-intercalation occurs in the graphite. Using the RG from spent LIBs, the NIC has been fabricated with commercial AC as the cathode to explore this phenomenon in 0.5 M NaPF6 in tetra ethylene glycol dimethyl ether [23]. In this work, the graphite was recovered from Cu foil using de-ionized water initially and completely recovered using DMF as well as separated the Li, which would be available on the anode surface because of the continuous charge-discharge cycles. The electrochemical performance of the RG was also compared with the commercial graphite in the same electrolyte. Moreover, the percentage contribution of both diffusion intercalation and pseudocapacitive intercalation was calculated for this process. The NIC in half-cell displayed an initial capacity of 74 mAh g−1 and retained 95% original capacity after 200 cycles. When fabricated pre-sodiated graphite with AC cathode, the NIC could provide energy of ∼60 Wh kg−1 at a power density of ∼57 W kg−1 (Fig. 8e). After 5000 cycles, the cell maintained ∼98% of its initial capacity in ambient conditions. Further, the galvanostatic charge-discharge test was performed to evaluate the NIC at four different temperatures at a current density of 0.025 A g−1. At high temperatures, the charge-discharge time is higher than that at ambient conditions; however, the cell exhibits a fast charge-discharge process at low temperatures, which can be seen in Fig. 7(d). Even at a high temperature (50 °C), the waste graphite assembled NIC attained a superior energy density of ∼71 Wh kg−1 incites to make novel high-performance energy storage devices by reusing the spent LIB electrodes. 5.3 Gas storage The world is facing more environmental problems of unprecedented climate change and increasing sea level because of the high emission of greenhouse gases, particularly the anthropogenic CO2 damaging the atmosphere. The CO2 concentration in the atmosphere has been increasing every year, and it is reported to cross 550 ppm from the current situation of ∼415 ppm. Fossil fuel-fired power plants are the major contributor to CO2 emissions in addition to other activities like deforestation, fuel-based vehicles, and chemical processes. Therefore, more technologies like adsorption using solid adsorbents have been dedicated to capturing CO2 from power plant benefits to attain a green environment, and further, the solid adsorbents can be disposed of easily to the environment without any precautions. In order to resolve these above-mentioned issues, hydrogen is the preferable choice attributable to its high abundance and pollution-free emissions. However, storing this clean fuel in a larger amount is a critically challenging issue, and the tactic to store on the porous adsorbents is receiving enormous interest. In the above-mentioned cases, porous carbons are very attractive owing to their lightweight, high surface area, and low cost for adsorption studies. Bearing these issues in mind, Bajaj and co-workers [177] followed their previous procedure to prepare reduced graphene oxide from spent LIBs sources in order to examine their properties for the gas storage applications (i.e., H2 and CO2) along with the carbonized separator. Most importantly, the rGO prepared from spent graphite and Al exhibited a higher BET surface area of 374 m2 g−1, indicating its porous nature without involving any activation treatment. Because of electrostatic attraction, the as-prepared rGO could able to store 1.78 wt% of H2 at 77 K, whereas its uptake reached 0.13 wt% at 298 K up to 40 bar pressure. It is noted that the adsorption capacity met saturation at 15 bar pressure in 77 K, and no changes were observed at 298 K when the pressure increased up to 40 bar. In the case of CO2 adsorption, rGO had a capacity for the uptake of 12 wt% at 298 K in 40 bar pressure. In both H2 and CO2 adsorption, the carbonized separator in the form of hollow spheres showed promising results as a result of their high surface area and 3D morphology, which carbonized in one step in the absence of a template. This inspiring approach directed another route to recycle and reuse the components of spent LIBs for gas storage applications. 5.4 Wastewater treatment Researchers found other prospects to reuse the spent graphite for dye adsorption applications. The spent LIBs graphite was recovered via DMF treatment, and its derivative graphene oxide was prepared using Hummer’s method. Both graphite and GO were evaluated as adsorbents on the adsorption of cationic methylene blue and anionic congo red dyes. Moreover, the influence of carbon materials weight, adsorption time, dye concentration, temperature, and pH of the dye solutions were detected for the adsorption studies. The obtained experimental values were further fitted with the Freundlich and Sips isotherm models to determine the distribution of dye molecules on the GO surface. The dye interaction with the GO and the adsorption mechanism was verified through the Pseudo-second order and Elovich kinetic models. Also, it is found that the prepared GO from waste graphite is able to adsorb 134.4 mg g−1 congo red dye and completely remove the 1000 mg g−1 of methylene blue by electrostatic attraction [178]. Similar to dyes, water bodies are facing the major issue of eutrophication due to excess primary nutrients like phosphate from various sources, and it needs to be removed before runoff into natural water bodies, which can deteriorate the aquatic systems. Among current technologies, a simple adsorption method with cost-effective adsorbents is believed to remove the effluents efficiently on a large scale. Zhang et al. [179] demonstrated the adsorption ability of phosphate with recovered anode material after making the composite with MgO, facilitated the adsorption process via phosphate precipitation from the wastewater. Further, the adsorption mechanism was fitted well with the Langmuir-Freundlich model and found the process was involved in the heterogeneous multilayer adsorption, which has the capacity to uptake 588.4 mg g−1 of phosphate. Similarly, Zhao et al. [180] utilized the spent graphite powder for heavy metal removals such as Pb, Cd, and Ag, as well as compared the adsorption capacity after modifying the graphite with MnO2. The MnO2-modified graphite proved its superior adsorption capacity by removing 99.9% of Pb2+, 79.7% of Cd2+, and 99.8% of Ag+ through the exchange of OH− groups. Recently, advanced oxidation processes receiving great attention in order to remove this kind of contaminants from wastewater as a result of their fast reaction rates by generating active radicals. Wang et al. [181] prepared the reduced graphene oxide from spent LIBs graphite using three different techniques of hydrothermal, chemical reduction, and stepwise calcination treatment to perform catalytic ozonation of organic pollutant oxalic acid. These three graphene samples prepared from three different methods were tested in the catalytic ozonation of oxalic acid and revealed the graphene obtained from the hydrothermal treatment displayed better catalytic activity because of the highest structural disorder which was established by the ratio difference between the sp2 and sp3 carbon. As a result of this higher defective level, hydrothermally derived graphene fully removed the oxalic acid within 45 min, whereas the rGO derived from commercial graphite could achieve 95% removal only within 1 h. Also, this spent graphite-derived graphene showed three times good reusability towards the adsorption of nitrophenol as well as the corresponding total organic carbon rate also decreased from 92 to 62%, as shown in Fig. 9 (a and b). In a similar way, the Electro-Fenton process is another promising advanced oxidation technology for pollutants remediation via the effective formation of hydroxyl radical (OH∙) as a powerful oxidant in the process which can be produced through the electrochemical generation of H2O2, thereby activation with Fe2+ ions [182]. The formation of H2O2 is favoured by oxygen flow that enables the two-electron reduction of O2 at the cathode. Cao et al. [182] reused the spent LIB anode material as a cathode in the Electro-Fenton process for bisphenol A removal. They treated the graphite with acid as one sample (AL) and lixiviation with acid and alkali as another sample (AAL) to dissolve all metals present in the graphite. It is well-known that the degradation performance mainly depends on the yield of H2O2 in the electro-Fenton process. The property of spent material was evaluated without pollutants during the electro-fenton process for detecting the H2O2 production (Fig. 9c). Among these two graphitic samples, AL was able to remove 100% of bisphenol A within 70 min. In contrast, AAL attained only 82% in 130 min. This difference is due to the distribution of Fe in the different leaching processes which played as another fenton reagent in the electro-Fenton system (Fig. 9d). 6 Conclusion and future perspective Various reports are pointing out only the highest supply risk of Li and Co with respect to its source reserves and supply reliability, not concerns about the “possible future critical material graphite,” which demand is rapidly rising year by year and it may extend up to next decade considering the dominance of LIBs, especially in the EVs as an anode material. Though, the “second-life” for EV batteries is proposed in low-power/requirement applications like power management in residential and commercial areas, power grid stabilization, and renewable energy storage systems, in which the spent LIB can able to retain the power of 70 to 80% for several years. This “second use” policy delays the LIBs to reach the final destination of the recycling spot, which is considered a “short-term” solution. Nevertheless, parallelly, existing industrial technologies give prominence to the metal-rich cathode recycling, and other components like valuable material graphite used to be burned in the pyrometallurgical process or employed as a reducing agent in the recycling industries such as Umicore, Accurec, Sony, and Aalto during the process. The OnTo process only effectively recovers the graphite for the LIB application under supercritical conditions followed by the thermal treatment; nevertheless, this technique requires pH control to complicate the recycling process. Some other processes like LithoRec have not mentioned the use of graphite after recovery from the leaching process. The recovery of graphite from spent LIBs is still in the research phase since the industries could not further develop the process on a large scale due to the inability to balance the relationship between pollution and cost. Researchers explored the usage of chlorine gas for graphite purification; however, toxic Cl2 corrodes the equipment. In some cases, high temperature (2500–3300 °C) is used to repair the spent graphite structure where the residual metals would be easily eliminated through gasification. However, this strategy increases the recycling cost and requires more energy for the graphite renovation. Also, many studies have been utilized strong acids as a leaching agent to revamp the graphite structure, generating secondary pollution, which limits the large-scale process. Therefore, new strategies should be focused on avoiding the secondary pollution forming from strong acids during the hydrothermal treatment. Recently, boric acid has been used as a leaching agent to renovate the graphite from spent LIBs [183]. Compared to strong acids like HCl, HNO3, and H2SO4, weak boric acid with a pKa value of 9.2 will provide significant environmental advantages for graphite renovation. Further, the advantage of using boric acid is that it helps to get doped on the surface besides healing the graphite structure, which also improves the electrochemical performance. The regenerated graphite from this method delivered 332 mAh g−1 at C/3 and retained ∼100% of its initial capacity after 100 cycles, encouraging to development of more environmentally sustainable technologies for the industrial-scale up process. However, still, techniques need to be upgraded for increasing the graphite specific capacity along with less graphite degradation, such as acid-free purified graphite and low-temperature graphitization repair. Surface modification is another approach to enhance the graphite capacity that decreases the graphite degradation and irreversible capacity as well as reduces the challenges in graphite recycling once the battery reaches its end of life. Besides, a recent study explored that graphite books for up to 40% of the greenhouse gases, 63% of SO x emissions, and 67% of NO x emissions regarding the cradle-to-gate impacts of 1 kWh NMC-type LIBs [184]. Also, Europe alone required ∼2,70,000 tons of battery-grade graphite in order to achieve the goal of 300 GWh per year of battery production. Moreover, graphite recovery from spent LIBs possibly will reduce the environmental footprint during battery production and simultaneously solve the recycling issues. Thus, the discordance of future demand material incites to recycle the anode part as a reusable one with proper technologies that could reduce the burden of resource dependency and will have a credit of “waste to wealth” approach besides acting as an environmental defender. This trend has to be changed with a suitable recycling process that should cover the recycling of all components effectively without leaving waste in a cost-effective manner and eco-friendly approach. Current research efforts making the possibility of reuse of graphite in various applications from batteries to wastewater treatment undoubtedly could lift the industrial spent LIBs recycling process to the next level. However, several concerns are involved in the lab-scale process, which appropriately need to be rectified before entering into the industries for the updated technologies. Generally, most of the LIBs contain graphite as the anode material constructed with the different types of Li-based cathodes, making it trouble to classify the spent LIBs according to their composition; however, recently, the colour codes have been introduced based on the cathode chemistry to avoid the confusion that could help the recyclers/industries for easy recycling. Obviously, the presence of impurities such as Al, Cu, or Fe could hinder the electrochemical performance of the anode material that needs to be eliminated or separated before reuse. Effective regeneration of graphite via treatment with water or acids has been studied for the LIB application; some reports are not involved in the process to recover lithium from the SEI layer on the surface of the anode material, which usually occurs as a result of the number of charge-discharge cycles. This approach could result in a huge amount of loss of lithium on a large scale in the industries which are considered the current critical material for LIB production. Therefore, the strong steps that need to be taken in the lab-scale recovery of lithium from the anode side along with economic analysis undeniably add another valuable product from the recycling as well as could help the process to be economical. In addition, the cost of the Cu current collector should be included together with the graphite material during the economic analysis of spent LIBs recycling [185]. The spinel Li4Ti5O12 anode-based LIBs are already available in the commercial market, in which Cu current collector is no longer required. Therefore, including the Cu current collector price is essential along with graphite [185]. Moreover, the structure of graphite may be available in damaged conditions during the recycling process, which opens up new prospects to reuse in dual-ion batteries and other charge-storage devices like alkali metal-ion supercapacitors (Na & K), flow batteries, etc. depending upon their level of damage. A high-cost material, graphene, and its derivatives have been prepared and applied as electrode/catalyst materials in energy conversion & storage, and wastewater treatment applications are still in the position to improve the physical characteristics such as surface area and porosity. Also, large-scale graphene preparation should be developed with high quality in order to contest with commercial graphene makes the recycling process economically, thereby extending their application in various fields from biomedical to sensors. By keeping the point of huge investments in the large-scale production of LIBs from portable electronics to automotive applications, the improved version of recycling technologies is urgently required to recycle all the components of spent LIBs, including graphite, in order to avoid the natural resources dependency and environmental pollution. From today’s standpoint, the recycling of all components of spent LIBs will lead to attaining higher sustainability, diminish the cost, and mainly ensures the production of low-cost energy storage devices. coredata.dc:description: Demand for graphite in the forthcoming years to develop Li-ion batteries (LIBs) with the goal of driving electric vehicles (EV) and its requirement in multifarious energy storage applications as an electrode. The emerging sector of LIB-based EVs, along with portable electronics, produces an inevitable volume of batteries in the e-waste stream. The main reason for the lower percentage of recycling (at present, <5%) is due to the recovery of economically rich metals like Li, Ni, and Co. However, complete recycling technologies, including the strategic material graphite, which is available in a massive amount of spent LIBs, are urgently needed to be updated to ensure the reuse of all components. This approach lifts the recycling process to develop an economic one besides the geostrategic and environmental policy aspects. Here, we summarize the importance of graphite and its demand and specify the reasons to recycle the graphite from spent LIBs along with its development as an anode in detail. Additionally, the approach of the current recycling process of graphite in lab-scale and industries for various applications, including energy storage, are discussed with the highlights of future progress.
